contentrichtext.text: {{other uses|Oom-Pah-Pah (disambiguation)}} [[File:Oom-pah.png|thumb|right|Oom-pah played by [[accordion]] on C [[major chord]] with [[alternate bass]] {{audio|Oom-pah.mid|Play}}.]] '''Oom-pah''', '''Oompah''' or '''Umpapa''' is the rhythmical sound of a deep [[brass instrument]] in a [[musical ensemble|band]], a form of background [[ostinato]].<ref>''Oompah'', The Oxford Pocket Dictionary of Current English, 2008</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/oompah |title=Oompah |publisher=YourDictionary}}</ref> The oom-pah sound is usually made by the [[tuba]] alternating between the root (tonic) of the [[chord (music)|chord]] and the 5th (dominant) — this sound is said to be the ''oom''. The ''pah'' is played on the off-beats by higher-pitched instruments such as the [[clarinet]], [[accordion]] or [[trombone]]. Oompah is often associated with ''[[Volkstümliche Musik]]'', a form of popular German music, and with [[polka]]. In [[triple time]] genres such as the [[waltz]] it is oom-pah-pah. The musical ''[[Oliver!]]'' contains a song named "[[Oom-Pah-Pah (song)|Oom-Pah-Pah]]", which is named after the oom-pah. A more modern variation is the playing of contemporary pop and rock songs in an Oompah style, by bands such as [[Global Kryner]] (Austria) and Oompah Brass (UK) who dubbed the style "Oompop".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oompahbrass.com |title=Oompah Brass |quote=Oompah Brass are now the world's leading (and only) exponents of 'Oom-pop', known for their Bavarian-style re-working of songs like Guns ‘n Roses’, Paradise City and Madonna’s Material Girl.}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Duple time]] *[[Carter Family picking]] *[[Eläkeläiset]] *[[Humppa]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{music-stub}} [[Category:Accompaniment]] [[Category:Bass (sound)]] [[Category:Onomatopoeias]] [[Category:Rhythm section]] [[la:Oom-pah]] Search Traditional German Oom-pah band on youtube for some good examples of Oom-Pah
